Flashcard: In Python, everything is an object - even numbers and functions!
Indentation defines structure in Python - forget braces, spacing matters.
Variables don't need types declared - Python figures them out automatically.
Strings can use single or double quotes - consistency matters more than choice.
Use '#' to add a comment - it's ignored by Python but loved by humans.
Python reads top to bottom, so order your logic carefully.
Use print() to display results - your first debugging tool.
Triple quotes let you write multi-line strings easily.
input() always gives you a string - even if you type a number.
Use type() to check what kind of object you're working with.
Lists are ordered and mutable - you can edit them anytime.
Tuples are like lists, but locked - once made, they can't change.
Sets automatically remove duplicates - great for unique collections.
Dictionaries store data in key-value pairs - like labeled boxes.
len() tells you how many items are inside a container.
Lists can hold anything - even other lists or functions!
Negative indexes count from the end - -1 is the last item.
Slicing lets you grab parts of sequences - [start:end:step] is the syntax.
Strings are immutable - you can replace them, not modify them.
Use sorted() to get a new sorted list - or sort() to change it in place.
Functions are created with def - short for define.
A function that doesn't return anything actually returns None.
Default arguments are evaluated once - not every call.
Use keyword arguments for clarity when calling functions.
Lambda functions are tiny throwaway functions - perfect for one-liners.
Functions are objects too - you can pass them around like data.
Use *args for variable arguments and **kwargs for named arguments.
Docstrings describe what your function does - use triple quotes right under def.
Recursion is a function calling itself - cool, but watch your base case!
return ends a function immediately and gives back a value.
for loops can go through any iterable - from lists to strings.
while loops run until their condition becomes False.
break stops a loop cold, while continue skips to the next round.
Use pass as a placeholder - it literally does nothing but keeps your code valid.
if, elif, else decide what runs based on truthiness.
Booleans in Python are capitalized - True and False.
None is falsy - just like 0, '', and empty collections.
Use 'in' to check membership - it works for lists, strings, and sets.
Chained comparisons like 1 < x < 10 make your code clean and readable.
Use ternary expressions like 'a if cond else b' to make compact decisions.
Classes group data and behavior - they're blueprints for objects.
__init__ sets up new objects - it's the constructor method.
self refers to the instance - it's how methods access data.
Class variables belong to the class, not each instance.
Inheritance lets a class reuse code from another class.
super() calls methods from the parent class - super useful!
Private attributes are just a naming convention - nothing truly private here.
Polymorphism means different objects can share method names and still work.
Magic methods like __str__ and __add__ let you customize built-in behavior.
Everything in Python OOP is built on top of object - the ultimate base class.
List comprehensions are compact loops that build lists on the fly.
Dict comprehensions let you create mappings in one neat line.
Generators use yield to return items lazily - one by one.
Iterators remember where they left off - that's why you can only loop once.
Decorators wrap functions to extend behavior - like adding extra powers.
Closures remember variables even after their function has finished.
with automatically cleans up resources - think of it as polite programming.
try and except help your code recover from errors instead of crashing.
finally always runs - no matter what happens in try/except.
Modules are Python files you can reuse - import keeps code DRY.
Everything is passed by object reference - Python doesn't copy by default.
The GIL allows only one thread to run Python code at a time.
Multiprocessing lets you sidestep the GIL using multiple processes.
Asyncio helps run many tasks concurrently using async and await.
Await can only be used inside async functions - never in normal ones.
Descriptors control attribute access at a deep level - used in properties.
Type hints improve readability and help static checkers - Python won't enforce them.
Metaclasses are classes of classes - yes, Python can go that deep.
F-strings are the modern way to format text - clean and efficient.
contextlib helps you build your own context managers with yield.
Lists are ordered and mutable - you can edit them anytime.

Default arguments are evaluated once - not every call.
